Nunc restat illud
Lombardus, Sent. I, d. xx
etc. This is distinction 44 in which, after the Master determined about the power of God with respect to the quantity of things produced, here he treats about this same type of power with respect to the goodness of those things.

And it is divided into three parts because in the first place he asks whether God would be able to make a thing in a more perfect degree, in the second whether in a better mode, third whether everything that was possible always is possible a uniform state. The second begins at
post haec considerandum
Lombardus, Sent. I, d. xxx
. The third begins at
praeterea quaeri solet
Lombardus, Sent. I, d. xxx
.
The first is divided into two parts because in the first place he recites the error of some and recites the same, in the second place he determines and approves the truth, which begins at
verum hic ab eis
Lombardus, Sent. I, d. xxx
.

The third principal part, namely
praeterea quaeri solet
Lombardus, Sent. I, d. xxx , is divided in three, for in the first place with respect to this question he considers a certain false opinion, in the second place he introduces his intention on the matter, in the third place he confirms his response. The second begins at
ad quod dicimus
Lombardus, I, d. xxx . The third begins at
fateamur
Lombardus, Sent. I, d. xxx
etc.
Whether omnipotence is productively able to make some power dependent on it better or more perfect in being or to increase its perfection.

That not because anything dependent on God is infinitely perfect, therefore no such thing is able to become more perfect either in being or essentially. The consequence is clear, and the antecedent is proved because any individual thing of a superior species infinitely exceeds the perfection of the individual of an inferior species because the former exceeds through the entire breadth of species producible between itself and the other species. But these producible thing are infinite, therefore anything exceeding in this way is infinitely perfect.

In the second place, if something created were able to be made better in being it follows that this would be a being closer to the highest independent being than the previous. The consequent is false because any dependent thing is infinitely distant from God in terms of perfection, therefore not created this closer to him than any other. The consequence is clear because nearness to the highest being seems to be a part of the perfection of things.

In the third place, if God perfected man essentially, then either man would remain in the human species or not. Not the first because any specific perfection consists in something indivisible, just as the species of any number. But if the second option is granted then it follows that man is not improved in terms of perfection or essentially. The consequences is clear because from the fact that he ceased to be in the human species, he ceased to be a man, therefore the question is false.

In opposition is the
Master in the present distinction
Lombardus, Sent. I, d. xxx
. And it is also proved by reason since to any finite perfect God is able to add some grade of perfection. But every thing dependent on God is of a finite perfection, therefore the question is true.

First conclusion: any species externally producible, just as it is of a limited perfection, so no such species exceeds another intrinsecally, quidditatively, or infinitely.
The first part is proved because, it this were the case, then it would follow that infinity would contain denominations of perfection absolutely. The consequent is false because then it would be God. And the consequence is clear because, if the opposite of the consequent were granted, it would follow that it is not intrinsically perfect absolutely and infinitely, which is the opposite of the antecedent. This is confirmed becase, just one intensively infinite thing does not exceed another intensively infinite thing, so perfectionally infinite thing does not exceed another perfectionally infinite thing. The second part is proved because the quiddity of any species is finite, therefore it only exceeds another finitely. The consequences is clear since what is exceeded is not greater than what is exceeding. The antecedent is clear because the quiddity of a thing is not greater than the intrinsic perfection of it is.

First corollary: though no species exceeds another absolutely infinitely, nevertheless the highest thing necessarily equally immeasurably exceeds anything created. This is clear because whatever it exceeds it exceeds completely since it is perfection, super simple, and indivisible, therefore.

Second corollary: though no two species are equally perfect absolutely, nevertheless the highest thing necessarily equally immeasurably exceeds any created species. Or said another way, though is more perfect than a donkey, nevertheless they are equally exceeded by God. The first is clear.

Third corollary: if some species were to contain infinite
individuals, it would not be on account of this that that it is more perfect then that it is now. Or the third corollary can be said thus, that any species of latitude beyond what is producible is comparable to another in any mode. This is clear because any finite thing is comparable to another finite thing in some mode.

Another corollary: it is both repugnant that two species are similarly equal in imperfection and it is repugnant that these be compared in some specific perfection. This is clear because whatever things are compared it is necessary that they be compared in some similar denomination of perfection which is common to each and predicable of each thing being compared because blackness is not able to be compared to whiteness in terms of blackness, but rather in terms of color according to which one of them is a more intense color, or a weaker, or a more perfect color than the other.

Second conclusion: though de facto some two species are immediate, nevertheless between any two species are infinite producible species. This is clear because between the human and angelic species there is de facto nothing in between. The second part is proved since the excess of one species over another is divisible, and consequently divisible according to an imaginable continuous quantity, and thus according to the points of this quantity there are more perfect producibile things and less perfect things, and since the points of this quantity are infinite, the proposed follows. The antecedent is clear because what is indivisible is not made better or more perfect

First corollary: that there are not more producible species are between God and non-degree than there are producible speces between man and the angels. This is clear because there are infinite producible in both cases.

The second corollary: just as the specific perfection or the perfection of a created entity does not apply precisely to the replication of the unity of the divine, so perfections of the species are not universally disposed or formed like the species of numbers. The first is clear because then it would follow that an angel would have greater perfection than understanding and willing. The consequent is false because there is nothing greater revealed in scripture. And the consequence is clear, the reason is because man has these perfections because man is able to understand and to will. The second part is proved because between the binary and tertiary there is no producible in between species, as there is between specific perfections.

Third corollary: just as any specific perfection consists in something indivisible really absolutely, so no superior species contains an inferior species formally. This is clear because such a perfection is punctual and just as when a unity is added or removed the species varies in number, so, according to the
Philosopher in VII of the Metaphysics
Aristoteles, Metaphysica VII, xxx
, when some essential grade is added to something its definition and its perfection is changed. The second part is proved because, if this were true, then it would follow that man would formally a donkey. The consequence is clear because, according to the
Philosopher in VII of the Metaphysics ,
formal parts are predicate in direction from the defined
Aristoteles, Metaphysicase, VII, xxx . Again, it would follow that a donkey would formally be just and justice. This is clear having supposed that the whole perfection of a substance is above the whole perfection of an accident according to some.

Third conclusion: though no created thing remaining below the limits of its own species is able to be made better by God intrinsically essentially, nevertheless given any created thing God is able to make it better to produce something in it perfectionally better. The first part is proved because through the addition of any essential grade the specific perfection is changed. The antecedent is clear through what has been said since such perfections consists in something indivisible. For this reason
the Philosopher in book VIII of the Metaphysics
Aristoteles, Metaphysicae VIII
compares in number the definition or perfection of a thing because, just as when unity is granted or removed from some number the species of the number changes, so having added or removed some essential grade the species of the thing or the definition is changed. The second is clear through what has been said because by any finite perfection God is able to produce something more perfect, therefore.

First corollary: though from omnipotence a supreme creatable thing is not able to be made,
nevertheless an infinite creatable thing is makeabl from itself. Each part is clear through
James of Viterbo in first quodlibet, question 2, article 1
Iacobus de Viterbo, Quodlibet I, q. 2, a. 1
, where he indicates that a perfectional line of the universe through pure actuality according to what is above and pure potential according to what is below is terminated and there is some intermediate grade mixed from actuality and potentiality. From this it is clear that any grade between the first and the infinite more greatly ought to be called potentiality than actuality because it is closer to pure potentiality than to pure actuality, to God who is pure act.

Second corollary: though it would not be the case that two species would be equally perfect essentially, nevertheless it is repugnant that two species are accidentally equal. The first part is clear because these two species are not more different than two individuals of the same species and thus they are not two species but one. The second part is proved because whiteness is able to be of the same intension and extension as blackness, and consequently equal in this respect. From what has been said it is clear in what sense the question is able to be conceded and in what sense it is able to be denied.

Against the first conclusion, it is argued that any grade of perfection absolutely below the immeasured is communicable to a creature through participation, therefore some producible species is or is able to be of an infinite perfeciton. The consequence holds, and the antecedent is proved because no great is repugnant to a creature, nor is one repugnant to another, since all concur at the same time in the divine essence, therefore nor is there repugnance on the part of communication because all things are communicated internally through his plenitude.

In the second place, God acts externally equally perfect as he does internally, therefore something external adequate to his power is able to correspond to him. The consequence is clear because what has an adequate term act this way internally.

In the third place, God begins to acquire a line of perfection absolutely, such that in the first proportional part of the hour he acquires so much perfection, and then in the second, etc. Then it follows that at the end of the hour the line will be completely acquired

In the fourth place against the first corollary, if this is the case, it follows that God would not be able to exceed a creature in terms of perfection. The consequent is false. The consequence is clear because less excess does not introduce distance or make better. But through the corollary he exceeds indivisibly, therefore minimally.

In the fifth place against the last, the first necessary is changeable by creatuires in an infinity of ways, therefore two species are able to be equal in perfection. The consequence holds, and the antecedent is proved because, just as God is mutable according to an imaginary line ascending and descending different ( species, so also is he mutable according to the transversal line which is equally distant from him according to his every part. This is confirmed through
Alanus, in De maximis theologiae, rule 8 , where he says,
God is an intelligible sphere whose center is everywhere but whose circumference is nowhere
Alanus de Insulis .

Against the second conclusion, an infinity of middles not communicating at the same time by the identity of species or genus destroys the specific finitude of the extremes, therefore it implies that there an infinity of things able to be produced between the two produced species. The consequence holds because for the opposite of the consequence the opposite of the antecedent is inferred, and the antecedent is proved because it implies that between the two specifically finite terms there are infinite specifically distinct middles.

' In the second place against the second corollary, is the
Philosopher, in book VIII of the Metaphysics , where he says that
species are like numbers, therefore there specific perfections are formed according to the mode of numbers.
Aristoteles, Metaphysica VIII, xxx
. Again Augustine
remove number from things and they are nothing.
Augustinus, xxx

In the third place against the same, because, if specific perfections are applied with respect to the replication of divine unity, then this would be because the constitutive reasons are not able to be communicated to others. The consequent is false because the rationale which is the constitutive ratio
of human beings is communicated to angels.

In the fourth place against the third corollary, a line of perfections is divisible, therefore it is composed from divisible things, therefore any species is divisible quantitatively, therefore it does not consist in something indivisible., indeed there are many points that correspond to it from which reason it has a divisible quantity.

In the fifth place against the same, because this species has a certain amount of perfection, therefore it has a certain quantity of perfection, therefore it has an intensive latitude, and consequently there are many points in the line of perfection that correspond to it absolutely.

Against the third conclusion: if the second part were true, then it would follow that specific creatable imperfection would be a process that goes on into infinity. The consequent is false because there is an essential order in those things, therefore etc.

In the second place against the first corollary, some species is able to given as being of a certain perfection, and then some species of greater perfection by two, and then some species greater by three, and so on into infinity, therefore something of an infinite perfection is able to be given.

In the third place, a line of perfection begins absolutely from the zero degree and is terminated in God, therefore some species is properly God just as some species is the zero degree. The consequence is clear from the fact that there are two extremes terminating this line.

In the fourth place against the second corollary, it is the case that there are two individuals of the species having the same perfection unequally absolutely, therefore it is the case that there are two species equally perfect essentially. The consequence is clear because the what sort of thing is the disposition or proportion of one individual species to the individual of another this is the disposition of the one species to the other. The antecedent is the article the soul of Christ is more perfect than the soul essentially. See the article.

In the fifth place, there are two beings which while differing in genus are equally perfect, therefore it is the case that there are two species etc equally perfect. The consequence is held because things that differ in genus differ in species. The antecedent is proved from the matter of the heavens and the matter of those inferior things, since one is changeable, able to be generated, and corruptible, but the other is not. But that they are equally perfect is proved because each terminates the entire latitude of possible being inclusively in the lower extreme or the zero degree, therefore they are equally distant from the first and highest point terminating the latitude going toward the upper extreme.

In the sixth place, man and the soul are of diverse species and are of the same essential or equal perfection, therefore. The antecedent is proved because one is the intrinsic essential ratio of the soul and the other of man, as is clear through their quidditative definitions, for man is called substance corporeal rational soul, but the soul is incorporeal. But the second part of the antecedent is proved because the whole is not less perfect than its pars, since the part is included in the whole, therefore man is not less perfect than its soul and especially since the soul communicates to the body its every essential and intrinsic perfection. But that the soul is not less intrinsically perfect than the composite is clear since every essential perfection of the composite is from a form which gives being to it Again, the soul contains every perfection of the composite virtually and in a more perfect mode than the composite itself, therefore it is intrinsically equally perfect.

To the first, the antecedent is denied when taking this collectively and in the composite sense. And when it is proved,
that no grade is repugnant
etc., this is conceded in the divided sense because neither a nor b nor c. Nevertheless it does not follow on account of this that everything is able to be at the same time and concur in the same thing or same species because this kind of infinite grade neither is nor is able to be.

In the second place, when it is said that,
it is not repugnant on the part of communication
etc., it is said that on the part of the creature it is impossible because it is repugnant to it that it is omnipotent being, per se being absolutely, necessary being and independent being. Again, such a creature
would be essentially justice, cognition, grace, love, and thus it would not be able to be deceived, to act obliquely, or to sin, indeed God would not be able to destroy or damn it. It is clear therefore that the repugnance is from the creature and from this kind of denomination to which it is repugnant to be communicationed to a creature

And to the second, it is said that, if the word equally perfectly notes or refers to acting, then the antecedent is conceded, and the consequence is denied because God is both places. But if it denotes or indicates a term of action, then the antecedent is denied. And if it is argued that God acts externally according to the last of his power, therefore he produces an infinite term, in this case it is responded that, if it is understood that it is not able to act perfectly, then the antecedent is denied. But if it is understood that it is not able to act through a more perfect power or mode, then the antecedent is conceded and the consequence is denied.

To the third, it is said that, if the case is possible in the last hour, then the nothing will be infinite; although something is perfect into infinity, nevertheless this is nothing according to which the nothing is something which is of infinite perfection. And if it is said that from all this God would be able to make one species, such that if God were to make this, then it would be so because it contains all things which man is in the what has been proposed, here in response it is said that it is not possible in this way for one thing to become from all things because no such thing is creatable or possible.
To the fourth, the consequence is denied. To the proof it is said, although it is indivisible, nevertheless everything divisible is eminently contained in this and therefore it exceeds immeasurably.

To the fifth, the consequence is denied, and when it is argued about a transverse line, it is said that it is imitatable precisely according to the transverse line for the same reason, but according to a different reason and another reason according to the straight line, such that the perfection of species should not be changed or imagined according to the transversal line.

To the sixth, it is said that God is the center of everything. But the from the center of circle to the circumference an infinity of lines are able to be had which while all connecting at the center equally by chance differ in species maximally, where the circle would be composed from parts of diverse rationes. In this same way it is able to be imagined about God and the diversity of species.

To the first against the second conclusion, it is said that the argument would conclude well if one did not include the other formally and equivalently, as is the case in the proposed, because an inferior species is included in the superior equivalently and supereminently. Therefore the argument does not work against the conclusion.

To the second, it is said that just as it is compatible with plurality, etc., and therefore this is explained by
Giles
Aegidius Romanos, xxx . In the first place, just as two species of number are not found equally distant from unity and there are no two species distant in this way, etc. In the second place, just as when unity is removed or added the species of number varies, so also etc. In the third place, just as a binary would be contained virtually in a ternary, so would a vegetative thing be contained in a sensitive thing and one species in another.

In the second place, it should be known that according to
Giles Aegidius Romanos, xxx
double is a distance both finite and infinite. The first is double because there is something in which an intermediate falls and another improper thing in which an intermediate is not able to be, like something punctual. It is also an infinite double because there is something in which any extreme indicates an essence, just as God and creatures are distant. There is a second improper thing in which only one extreme indicates an essence, and in this way prime matter and nothing are distant,
and thus they are said to be infinitely distant because between them there is no proportion. And thus it would be able to be said and to that verse from Wisdom
all things are constituted in number, weight, and measure
every entity is created in a certain number of organic parts and part of parts of the same quantity and of a certain genus and species. In the second place, that perfections and qualities of any being are in a certain number. Again, just as in number there is some lowest number so also in species. Again, just as numbers are immediate, so species are de facto immediate. Again, in weight, that is it gives to each their proper operations Again, in measure, that is they have a certain grade of perfection.
To the other part, it is said that Augustine wishes to say that all things are formed in certain organic and integral parts.

To the third, it is said that, if difference is taken for the first mode of speaking per se and in what sort, then rational is thus called a difference of human being But if it is taken in the second mode, then from this it is not distinguished from every species of another genus, and thus rational is not the ultimate difference of human being because it belongs to God and the angels But if is understood such that it is distinguished from all things which are of the same genus, then in this case it is a difference of human being because it distinguishes human being from ever other thing which is contained under animal. Through this it is clear for the conformation.

To the fourth, it is said that, just as a ternary thing is divisible and nevertheless is indivisibly ternary, so species is divisible and nevertheless it stands in something indivisible, such that there are specific degrees like an instant in time or a point in a line.

To the fifth, it is said that any species is a certain quantity of perfection because it eminently contains a perfection under this, nevertheless it does not follows that it has a formally intensive latitude such that many points correspond to it, just as it does not follow, a binary as such is a discrete quantity, therefore it is divisible into binaries.
To the first against the third conclusion, the consequent is able to be conceded because in numbers there seems to be an essential order and a process into infinity.

In the second place, it would be able to be said that it is not necessary that there is an essential order unless in those things which are produced in act because things are only properly comparable to one another which have a real and actual being. But finite species are de facto produced, therefore between them is an essential order.

To the second, it is said that into infinity some species is created or is able to be created perfect, and nevertheless nothing is perfect into infinity, therefore there is not able to be given a created species of infinite perfection.

To the third, it is said that this line does not terminate in God because God is an essence not included in that line but completely outside this line immeasurably exceeding it and any part of it, just as the eternity exceeds time. And it should not be imagined that something is as near to God in the same way that it is near to the zero-degree.

To the fourth, whatever is the case about the consequence, the antecedent is denied. To the article it is said that it is understood about natural dispositions and habits informing the soul of Christ which perfect or make better the essence of the soul.
To the fifth, the antecedent is denied. To the proof, it is said that it is possible for there to be a doubt about whether there is matter there.
In the second place, it is able to be said that, though there would be matter, nevertheless it would not be of the same species with the matter of inferior things.
In the third place, it is said that, if this were the case, then matter is in both places because each is transmutabile inasmuch as it is from its own part.

In the fourth place, it would be said that it they were of diverse species, then the other would not terminate the entire latitude of creatable being, indeed in the line of perfection diverse points would correspond to them.

To the sixth,
in the first place it is said that the soul does no communicate to the body any of its own perfect being by a perfection absolutely because the soul is formally life, formally indivisible, formally an intellective form, whence a principle and measure. And it happens that none of these formally communicate to the body or to a human being because a human being is not formally life nor intellect

In the second place, it is said that some species are composite and some are simple. But to a composite species in a line of perfection there are two corresponding points absolutely one according to one form and another according to the other form. Therefore, though there is one species, nevertheless they are able to be called two secundum quid. From this fact it is clear that a human being is more perfect than the soul, at least by extensive perfection.

In third place, it would be able to be said that the corollary is understood about simple species to which correspond absolutely one point in the line of perfection or it is understood about species completely distinct one of which is not included in the other as its part.
To the arguments to the contrary, it is clear what should be said through the what is said in the corollaries and in the conclusions and also in the solutions to the arguments.

Nevertheless it should be noted for the sake of the matter that the approach or drawing near of the creature to the highest happens in two ways. One is the extrinsic approach of that perfect and this is measured according to the distance which is between this perfection and God and because any distance between God and a creature is infinite, therefore the approach of the creature to God is not measured according to this sort of extrinsic distance. The other is the intrinsic distance of the creature and this is between the specific perfection and the zero-degree of perfection absolutely because any superior thing contains eminently the entire latitude of perfection of its inferior, and this is more properly called the approach to the highest than the previous approach which is extrinsic to the creature.

In the second place, it should be noted that an approach to the highest in this mode is an acquisition of divine participation and the better this participation, the more perfect the creature is. And this is not therefore because the more similar the creature is to God, the more it participates in divine goodness, but rather the reverse because the more greatly it participates in divine goodness, therefore the more similar it is to God because the foundation is prior to the relation and the cause is prior to the effect.

Again, the more creature participates, the more it imitates God, thus the approach of the creature to God is the same as its departure from the zero-degree, though the specific perfect is properly measured through the approach to the highest degree rather than through its departure from the zero-degree because as an approach it is something positive whereas as a departure it is something privative.

Nunc illud restat
Lombardus, I, d. xxx
etc. The first conclusion: that God is able to do things different than what he does and those things he does he would be able to do better. Whence God would have been able have made a human being would not have been able to sin or did not wish to sin, and if he would have made such a person, then he would have made something better than what he made.

Second conclusion: that God regarding those things which he makes some would be able to made in a better way and some in a worse way than he made them such the phrase otherwise or other mode relate to the quality of the creature and not to the wisdom of the builder, for the wisdom would not be able to make what it makes better or worse than what it de facto makes.

Third conclusion: that God is able to do whatever he was at one time able to do and he always wishes whatever he at one time wished, that is he has the power and will which he at one time had. Whence he is able to be incarnated by the same power that he was incarnated just as he is the same knowledge by which he knew that would be resurrected and knows that he was resurrected. Nevertheless he is not always able to make everything that he was at sometime able to do nor does he always wish to be or to become but was or was made, and thus about his knowledge it should be said in the same mode.
